qas.question: What is one straightforward case of a probabilistic test?
What does the Fermat primality test depend upon?

answers.text: np≡n (mod p) for any n if p is a prime number
np≡n (mod p) for any n if p is a prime number
np≡n (mod p) for any n if p is a prime number
the fact (Fermat's little theorem) that np≡n (mod p) for any n if p is a prime number

context: A particularly simple example of a probabilistic test is <a0_0><a0_4><b5_0>the <a0_1><a0_2><a0_3>Fermat primality<b5_0/> test<a0_4/><a0_3/><a0_2/><a0_1/>,<a0_0/> which relies on <a1_4>the fact (Fermat's little theorem) that <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2><a1_3><b6_0>np≡n (mod p)<b6_0/><a1_0/> for any n if p is a prime number<a1_4/><a1_3/><a1_2/><a1_1/>. If we have a number b that we want to test for primality, then we work out nb (mod b) for a random value of n as our test. A flaw with this test is that there are some <a2_0><b7_0>composite numbers (the <a2_1><a2_2><a2_3><a2_4>Carmichael<a2_2/><a2_1/> numbers<a2_4/><a2_3/>)<b7_0/><a2_0/> that satisfy the Fermat identity even though they are not prime, so the test has no way of distinguishing between prime numbers and Carmichael numbers. Carmichael numbers are substantially rarer than prime numbers, though, so this test can be useful for practical purposes. More powerful extensions of the Fermat primality test, such as the <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2><a3_3><a3_4><b8_0>Baillie-PSW<b8_0/><a3_3/><a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/>,<a3_4/> <a4_1><a4_2><a4_3><a4_4>Miller-Rabin<a4_4/><a4_3/><a4_2/><a4_1/>, and <a4_0><b9_0>Solovay-Strassen tests<b9_0/><a4_0/>, are guaranteed to fail at least some of the time when applied to a composite number.
